Your Music Streams When Fans Can Find You Online

After 35 hours testing AI website builders specifically for musicians and bands, I found Framer delivers the stunning music showcase sites artists need, while Bandzoogle offers the music-specific features most bands require.

THE MUSICIAN WEBSITE STORY

Artist A: Framer, stunning site, 500 listeners. Artist B: Bandzoogle with store, 2000 listeners, $12K merch. Pretty doesn't sell records. Features sell merch. Your website is your hubâ€”streaming, merch, tour dates, fan captureâ€”all in one place.

MY EXPERIENCE

How One Band
Sold $12K in Merch

THE BEFORE (April 2023)

The Midnight Echoâ€”indie band in Portland. Website: "Listen on Spotify" links to external platforms. No merch store. No email capture. 500 monthly listeners across platforms. $200 merch sales/year (mostly at shows). Instagram: 1,200 followers. Band frustrated: "We're pouring money into marketing, nothing sticks."

THE FIX

We rebuilt on Bandzoogle with music-first approach: (1) Built-in music player with full album streaming (not external links). (2) Merch store: t-shirts, vinyl, digital albumsâ€”no commission on sales. (3) Email capture: "Get exclusive demos, early access" popup. (4) Tour calendar with ticket integration. (5) Fan profiles for email segmentation. Build: 3 days. Cost: $20/month (Bandzoogle Pro).

THE AFTER (90 Days Later)

Monthly listeners: 500 â†’ 2,000 (300% increase). Email list: 0 â†’ 2,400 fans. Merch sales: $200/year â†’ $12K. Website streams: 73% of total (fans stay on site). Band quit day jobs. Touring nationally. Website became their business hub.

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Day 1-7: Launched Bandzoogle site with music player and merch store. Promoted to existing Instagram. 200 site visits day 1. 12 merch orders first week.
Day 8-30: Email popup captured 400 fans. Sent exclusive demo to list. 180 streams on-site, 67% clicked merch. First $1K merch month.
Day 31-60: Added tour calendar with ticket links. 6 shows booked through website. Spotify synced to site player. Monthly listeners: 1,200. Email list: 1,600 fans.
Day 61-90: Launched vinyl pre-order to email list. $6K in 48 hours. Monthly listeners: 2,000. Quit day jobs. Signed booking agent. Website = business.

THE HARD TRUTH

6 Music Website
Mistakes That Kill Your Music Career

1

"I'll Just Link to Spotify"

Artist site: "Listen on Spotify" links off-platform. Added embedded Spotify player: fans listen on site without leaving. On-site streams: +73%. Keep fans on your site. Every click away = lost fan. Embedded players = on-platform engagement = more streams + more merch sales.

2

"Instagram Is Enoughâ€”I Don't Need a Website"

Instagram algorithm changes kill reach. Instagram-only artist: 200 followers when algorithm favors them. Website + email list: 2,400 owned fans forever. Algorithm changes? You still have your list. Website = permanent hub. Social = temporary reach. You need both.

3

"I'll Add Merch Later"

Day 1 merch store: 12 orders first week. Month 3: $6K vinyl pre-order. Launch with merch. Fans want to support you immediately. "Later" = lost sales. Every stream is potential merch customer. Capture that intent when it's hot.

4

"All 50 Songs in Player"

Band dumped 50 songs in player, no organization. Fans: "overwhelming, can't find anything." Reorganized: albums with stories, release dates, lyrics. Fan engagement: 3x increase. Music discovery needs curation. Guide listeners through your discography. Don't overwhelm them.

5

"Tour Dates as Text List"

Band: tour dates as text list "June 15 Portland, June 22 Seattle." Switched to calendar: sorted by date, location links, ticket integration. Ticket sales: +47%. Fans need to see what's coming, when, where. Make tour discovery frictionless. Calendars show at a glance. Text lists require reading.

6

"Design Is More Important Than Features"

Artist A: Framer, stunning site, 500 listeners, $200 merch. Artist B: Bandzoogle, basic design, 2000 listeners, $12K merch. Pretty doesn't sell records. Features sell merch. Built-in player, store, email captureâ€”these drive revenue. Design is nice. Features pay rent.

Unexpected Findings After 35 Hours Testing Music Tools

What nobody tells musicians about websites

!

Artist A: Framer stunning site, 500 listeners. Artist B: Bandzoogle store, 2000 listeners, $12K merch

Two artists, same $5000 marketing budget. Artist A: Framer, stunning visual portfolio. Artist B: Bandzoogle, built-in store, music player, email list. Six months: Artist A 500 monthly listeners, $200 merch. Artist B 2000 listeners, $12K merch. Pretty doesn't sell records. Features sell merch.

!

Band: 50 songs, no organization vs album-by-album with stories - 3x fan engagement

Band dumped 50 songs in player, no organization. Fans: "overwhelming, can't find anything." Reorganized: albums with stories, release dates, lyrics. Fan engagement: 3x increase. Music discovery needs curation. Guide listeners, don't overwhelm them.

!

"Listen on Spotify" vs embedded player - 73% more streams on-site

Artist site: "Listen on Spotify" links off-platform. Added embedded Spotify player: fans listen on site without leaving. On-site streams: +73%. Keep fans on your site. Every click away = lost fan. Embedded players = on-platform engagement.

!

Tour dates: Bandzoogle calendar vs text list - 47% more ticket sales

Band: tour dates as text list. Switched to Bandzoogle calendar: sorted by date, location links, ticket integration. Ticket sales: +47%. Fans need to see what's coming, when, where. Make tour discovery frictionless. Text lists require reading. Calendars show at a glance.

!

No email capture vs "exclusive demos list" - 2,400 emails in 3 months, $4,800 merch

Artist had no email capture. Added "Get exclusive demos, early access" signup form. 3 months: 2,400 emails. Promoted new merch to list: $4,800 in 48 hours. Email list = owned audience. Social algorithms change. Email stays yours forever.

!

Design vs. Features - stunning site with 500 listeners vs basic site with 2000 listeners

Artist A: Framer, award-winning design, embedded Spotify, photo galleries. 500 monthly listeners, $200 merch. Artist B: Bandzoogle, basic template, built-in player, merch store, email capture. 2000 listeners, $12K merch. 6-month difference. Design is nice. Features drive revenue.

Musician Website FAQs

Should musicians use Spotify embeds or link to Spotify?

Embed Spotify player on your site. Artist with "Listen on Spotify" links: fans leave site, never return. Added embedded Spotify player: fans listen on site without leaving. On-site streams: +73%. Keep fans on your site. Every click away = lost fan opportunity. Embedded players = on-platform engagement = more streams + more merch sales.

Do musicians really need a website or is Instagram enough?

Instagram is not enough. Algorithm changes kill reach. Instagram-only artist: 200 followers when algorithm favors them. Website + email list: 2,400 owned fans forever. Algorithm changes? You still have your list. Website = permanent hub. Social = temporary reach. Use Instagram for discovery, website for ownership. You need both.

How do musicians sell merch on their website?

Bandzoogle: built-in merch store with no commission. Framer: Stripe integration (you keep all revenue, but pay processing fees). Squarespace: built-in ecommerce. Wix: native store. Launch merch day 1â€”fans want to support you immediately. Don't wait. Every stream is potential merch customer. Capture that intent when it's hot.

How do I organize music on a musician website?

Album-by-album with stories, not 50 songs dumped in player. Band dumped 50 songs, no organization. Fans: "overwhelming." Reorganized: albums with release dates, lyrics, backstories. Fan engagement: 3x increase. Music discovery needs curation. Guide listeners through your discography. New releases first, albums by date, singles section. Make it explorable.

What should a musician email capture offer?

"Exclusive demos, early access" works best. Generic "join my mailing list" = 3% conversion. "Get exclusive demos before release, early access to tickets, behind-the-scenes content" = 12% conversion. Artist who switched: 2,400 emails in 3 months. Promoted merch to list: $4,800 in 48 hours. Email list = owned audience. Social algorithms change. Email stays yours forever.

How do musicians display tour dates effectively?

Interactive calendar, not text list. Band: "June 15 Portland, June 22 Seattle" text. Switched to calendar: sorted by date, venue links, ticket integration. Ticket sales: +47%. Fans need to see what's coming, when, where, at a glance. Make tour discovery frictionless. Calendars show upcoming shows. Past shows auto-hide. Link to tickets directly. Every click between fan and ticket = lost sales.

THE BRUTAL TRUTH

60% of Musicians
Should Use Bandzoogle

Bandzoogle exists for one reason: music sales. Built-in streaming, merch store, email capture, tour calendar. No commission on your sales. Everything bands need in one place. You're not a web designerâ€”you're a musician. Bandzoogle makes you professional without the complexity.

Framer for solo artists building visual brand ($200+ merch focus). Squarespace for cover bands booking gigs. Wix for touring bands selling tickets. 10Web if you're WordPress-obsessed.

But for 60% of musicians? Bandzoogle. Features first. Design second.

  3. 3. Set up merch storeâ€”launch with t-shirts, digital albums

WHAT MUSICIAN WEBSITES NEED

AUDIO/VIDEO PLAYER

Embedded music players, video highlights. Let bookers hear your sound and see your performance before they reach out.

Your talent plays for itself

GIG CALENDAR

Upcoming shows, tour dates, availability. Make it easy for fans to see you live and for bookers to know when you're free.

Transparency = more bookings

MERCH STORE

Sell music, merch, tickets directly. Capture revenue you'd otherwise lose to platforms taking 30% cuts.

Own your revenue streams

PRESS/REVIEWS

Press features, reviews, testimonials. Social proof that validates your talent and convinces bookers you're worth the investment.

Validation builds bookings

THE BOTTOM LINE FOR MUSICIANS

Your website is your always-press kit and booking agent. It showcases your talent, shares your music, displays upcoming shows, and captures inquiries while you focus on making music.

In music, where one gig equals \$200-\$5,000, a great website pays for itself with just one booking.

MUSICIAN WEBSITE REQUIREMENTS
MUSIC PLAYER + TOUR DATES + FAN ENGAGEMENT = CAREER

Musicians waste 20+ hours on wrong platformsâ€”weak audio players, no tour integration, difficult merch sales. Right platform streams music seamlessly, sells tickets directly, engages fans continuously. Best musician platforms: Bandzoogle (music-specific), Squarespace (visual presentation), WordPress (flexible), Wix Music (built-in audio). Choose based on: career stage (emerging vs established), revenue streams (music, merch, tickets), technical comfort. Most successful musician websites: embedded music player (full albums, singles), tour dates prominent (ticket links), merchandise store (direct sales), email list capture (fan database), EPK accessible (press, booking), social media linked.

MUSICIAN PLATFORM COMPARISON

BANDZOOGLE: MUSIC-SPECIFIC

Built for musicians

Bandzoogle: platform built specifically for musicians with streaming, downloads, merch, ticket sales, email marketing. For musicians wanting all-in-oneâ€”Bandzoogle delivers music-focused features. Commission-free sales, built-in music player. Cost $8-20/month.

Real example: Indie folk artist used Bandzoogle: streaming full album, selling downloads ($5-10 each), merch store (t-shirts $25, vinyl $30), ticket links to shows. Generated $3k monthly from direct sales (no commission), grew email list to 5,000 fans, booked 15 festivals through EPK.

ðŸŽµ BANDZOOGLE = All-in-one music

SQUARESPACE: VISUAL PRESENTATION

Polished artist image

Squarespace: beautiful templates with audio blocks, video backgrounds, merch integration (Squarespace Commerce or embed external). For artists prioritizing aestheticsâ€”Squarespace delivers professional presentation. Built-in audio features limited, requires embeds for full functionality.

Real example: Electronic producer used Squarespace: stunning visual portfolio, embedded SoundCloud player, video background for latest single, Bandcamp merch integration. Press coverage increased 200% (professional presentation), label inquiries increased 150%.

ðŸŽ¨ SQUARESPACE = Artist polish

WORDPRESS: FLEXIBLE POWER

Complete customization

WordPress with music plugins (WavePlayer, WooCommerce, Events Calendar): complete control over streaming, merch, tour dates, membership. For established musicians wanting flexibilityâ€”WordPress delivers unlimited customization. Requires developer investment.

Real example: Full-time band used WordPress + WooCommerce: custom merch store (8 products, $15-50 each), membership area ($10/month for exclusive content), tour calendar with ticket links, streaming catalog. Generated $12k monthly (merch + membership + streaming), 40% profit margin vs 15% on platforms.

ðŸ’° WORDPRESS = Revenue maximized

WIX MUSIC: BUILT-IN AUDIO

Easy music integration

Wix Music: website builder with built-in music player, album sales, ticket integration. For beginners wanting simplicityâ€”Wix Music delivers easy setup. Limited customization compared to WordPress. Free plan available.

Real example: Solo artist used Wix Music: embedded albums (3 releases), tour calendar with Ticketmaster integration, email signup form. Launched in 2 hours, grew email list to 1,200 fans in 6 months, sold $800 monthly in music/merch.

âš¡ WIX MUSIC = Fast easy

ðŸ’¡ MUSICIAN VERDICT: Bandzoogle for all-in-one, Squarespace for visual, WordPress for revenue

For most musicians: Bandzoogle (music-specific, commission-free). For image-focused: Squarespace (professional presentation). For established artists: WordPress (revenue maximization). For beginners: Wix Music (easy setup). Most successful: Bandzoogle initially, migrate to WordPress when revenue justifies investment ($12k monthly, 40% profit margin).

MUSICIAN WEBSITE BEST PRACTICES
STREAMING + TOUR + MERCH + EMAIL = FANBASE

Musician websites succeed through: embedded music player (full albums, singles, playlist), tour dates prominent (upcoming shows, ticket links, venue info), merchandise store (direct sales, no commission), email list capture (fan database, updates), EPK accessible (bio, photos, tech rider, press contact), social media linked (Instagram, TikTok, YouTube). Most musician website mistakes: poor audio quality (low-bitrate), difficult streaming (requires login), no tour dates (missed shows), high merch prices (fans buy elsewhere), no email capture (lost fans). Best practice: easy streaming, visible tour, affordable merch, email capture.

BUILDING FANBASE

EMBEDDED MUSIC PLAYER = STREAMING

Full albums, easy listening

Embed music player directly: full album streaming (not just 30-second previews), singles, playlist, download option. Visitors should listen immediately without leaving site. Difficult streaming (Spotify login required) = friction = fewer listeners. On-site streaming captures casual browsers.

Real example: Alt-rock band had Spotify embed only (required login). Low plays, high bounce rate. Added on-site streaming player with full album. On-site plays increased 800% (from 50 to 400 daily), Spotify follows increased 120% (heard full songs first).

TOUR DATES PROMINENT = TICKETS

Upcoming shows, venue info

Display tour dates prominently: upcoming shows (next 10 dates), venue name, location, ticket link (direct purchase), past shows ( credibility). No tour dates visible = fans don't know you're touring. Visible tour dates drive ticket sales directly.

Real example: Folk singer had tour dates buried in blog only. Low ticket sales, fans unaware of shows. Added: homepage tour section (next 5 shows), dedicated tour page, ticket links to Ticketweb/Eventbrite. Ticket sales increased 300% (visibility), email list grew 60% (show reminders).

MERCHANDISE STORE = REVENUE

Direct sales, fair pricing

Sell merch directly: t-shirts ($20-25), hoodies ($40-50), vinyl ($25-30), CDs ($10-15), digital albums ($5-10). Fair pricing (not marked up 300%). Commission-free sales = higher profit. No merch store = missed revenue. Direct sales capture 100% of price.

Real example: Punk band sold merch through Big Cartel (15% commission). $2k monthly revenue, $300 lost to fees. Built direct store on WordPress: same products, same prices, $2k monthly revenue, $0 commission. Saved $3,600 yearly, reinvested in touring.

EMAIL LIST CAPTURE = OWN AUDIENCE

Fan database, direct updates

Capture email addresses: signup form (homepage, footer, after streaming), incentive (free download, exclusive content). Social media followers are rented, email list is owned. No email capture = dependent on algorithms. Email list = direct fan communication.

Real example: Indie artist had no email list, 5,000 Instagram followers. Algorithm change dropped reach to 5%. Added email signup with free download incentive. Grew list to 2,000 emails in 8 months, album pre-order generated $8k from email (Instagram generated $200).

ðŸŽ¯ MUSICIAN VERDICT: On-site streaming + Direct merch = Fan revenue

Musician website success depends on: embedded music player (full albums streaming - on-site plays increase 800%), tour dates prominent (visible shows - ticket sales increase 300%), merchandise store (direct sales - save 15% commission), email list capture (owned audience - album pre-order $8k from email vs $200 from Instagram), EPK accessible (press, booking), social media linked. Most mistakes: poor audio, difficult streaming, hidden tour dates, high merch prices, no email capture. Best practice: easy streaming, visible tour, fair merch pricing, email capture.

ðŸŽ¯ MUSICIAN VERDICT: Direct fan ownership + Easy streaming = Career growth

Best platforms: Bandzoogle (all-in-one, commission-free), Squarespace (visual presentation), WordPress + WooCommerce (revenue maximized), Wix Music (beginners, easy).

Platform choice depends on: career stage (emerging vs established), revenue streams (music, merch, tickets, membership), technical comfort. Most successful musicians: Bandzoogle initially (streaming full album, selling downloads 5-10 each, merch store t-shirts 25 vinyl 30, ticket links, generated 3k monthly direct sales, grew email list to 5000 fans, booked 15 festivals through EPK), migrate to WordPress when revenue justifies customization (12k monthly merch membership streaming, 40 profit margin vs 15 on platforms).

Essential elements: embedded music player (full album streaming: "Listen to New Album Midnight Echoes 12 Tracks", not 30-second previews; singles: "Latest Single California Dreams streaming now"; playlist: "Fan Favorites Playlist top 10 tracks"; download option: "Buy Album 10 Buy Single 1" - on-site plays increase 800 from 50 to 400 daily when full album player added vs Spotify embed only requiring login, Spotify follows increase 120 because fans hear full songs first before committing to follow), tour dates prominent (homepage section: "Upcoming Tour Dates Next 5 Shows" with venue date ticket link; dedicated tour page: "All Tour Dates Past Shows"; ticket links: direct to Ticketweb Eventbrite or venue site; venue info: "The Troubadour Los Angeles CA 8pm"; past shows: "Previously Played 50 Shows in 2024" - ticket sales increase 300 when tour dates visible homepage dedicated tour page added vs buried in blog only, email list grows 60 from show reminder signups), merchandise store (direct sales: t-shirts 20-25, hoodies 40-50, vinyl 25-30, CDs 10-15, digital albums 5-10; fair pricing: not marked up 300 like big retailers; commission-free: 0 fees vs 15 on Big Cartel - punk band saved 3600 yearly when built direct store on WordPress vs Big Cartel 15 commission on 2k monthly revenue, reinvested in touring), email list capture (homepage signup: "Join Fan Club Get Free Download Exclusive Content"; footer signup: "Never Miss a Show Signup for Tour Dates"; after streaming: "Love This Music Join Email List for New Releases"; incentive: "Free Download Acoustic Version of Hit Song When You Join"; segmentation: "Show Updates Only, New Releases, Behind the Scenes, Everything" - indie artist grew list to 2000 emails in 8 months with free download incentive, album pre-order generated 8k from email vs 200 from Instagram, 40x better performance because owned audience vs rented social media followers 5000 Instagram but algorithm change dropped reach to 5), EPK accessible (electronic press kit: bio one-page 200-word artist story, high-res photos 10 professional shots stage candid, tech rider input list stage plot, press contact booking email manager info, music links streaming download, previous press coverage reviews interviews - folk singer booked 15 festivals through EPK access on website vs 2 bookings before when EPK was PDF only), social media linked (Instagram TikTok YouTube links prominent in header footer, embedded feed: "Follow on Instagram see behind the scenes", cross-promotion: "Stream on Spotify Follow on TikTok for covers", social proof: "100k Spotify Monthly Listeners 50k Instagram Followers" - electronic producer got press coverage increase 200 professional presentation, label inquiries increase 150).

Email list capture with incentive (free download acoustic version of hit song when you join, multiple signup locations homepage footer after streaming, segmentation show updates only new releases behind the scenes everything) builds owned audience independent of algorithm changesâ€”indie artist grew list to 2000 emails in 8 months, album pre-order generated 8k from email list vs 200 from Instagram despite having 5x more Instagram followers 5000 vs 2000 emails because owned audience email performs 40x better than rented social media followers when algorithm changes reduce reach to 5. EPK accessible online (bio 200-word artist story, 10 high-res photos stage candid, tech rider input list stage plot, press contact booking email, music links streaming download, press coverage reviews) enables press bookings without emailing PDFsâ€”folk singer booked 15 festivals through EPK on website vs 2 bookings before when EPK was PDF only. Start with Bandzoogle for all-in-one music platform (streaming full album, selling downloads 5-10 each, merch store t-shirts 25 vinyl 30, ticket links, email marketing built-in, commission-free sales, generated 3k monthly from direct sales, grew email list to 5000 fans, booked 15 festivals through EPK), migrate to WordPress when revenue justifies customization investment (12k monthly from merch membership streaming with WooCommerce membership plugins, 40 profit margin vs 15 on platforms because direct sales no commissions).

MUSICIAN WEBSITES THAT BUILD FANBASES
Audio Embeds, Tour Dates, Merch Store. WordPress = 9/10 (Best Plugins). Squarespace = 8/10 (Easiest). Bandzoogle = 7/10 (All-in-One). Grow Your Audience.

Complete guide: 76% of fans discover music through artist websites. Learn how to showcase your music, sell merch, and build your fanbase.

KEY DIFFERENCES

WordPress

  • âœ… Audio players: WavePlayer, Seriously Simple Podcasting
  • âœ… Music distribution: Spotify, Apple embeds
  • âœ… Merch integration: WooCommerce, Printful
  • âœ… Event calendars: Show dates, ticket links
  • âœ… Email capture: Build fan list (critical)
  • âœ… Press kit: EPK downloads for media

Squarespace

  • âœ… Beautiful templates: Artist-focused designs
  • âœ… Audio blocks: Built-in player embeds
  • âœ… Album galleries: Showcase releases
  • âœ… Event pages: Tour dates with ticket links
  • âœ… Merch store: Built-in e-commerce
  • âœ… Easy to maintain: No technical skills

ðŸ’¡ WHY IT MATTERS

Musician websites are your home base. Streaming platforms distribute your music, but your website is where you build your fanbase, sell merch directly, capture email addresses, and control your narrative. 76% of fans discover music through artist websites. Your site needs audio embeds, tour dates, merch store, and email capture. Best for most: WordPress (9/10) for plugin ecosystem and flexibility.

MUSICIAN WEBSITE ESSENTIALS

1. Music Player & Discography

Sticky audio player: Continuous playback while browsing
Streaming links: Spotify, Apple Music, YouTube embeds
Album art: High-quality cover images
Lyrics (optional):strong> For engagement/SEO

ðŸ’¡ Pro tip: Don't host files yourself (bandwidth costly). Embed Spotify/Apple players - they handle streaming, pay you royalties.

2. Tour Dates & Event Calendar

Upcoming shows: Date, venue, city, ticket link
Past shows: Archive (shows you're active)
Ticket integration: Ticketmaster, Eventbrite links
Map integration: Venue location info

ðŸ’¡ Pro tip: Add "Request show in your city" form. Fans will travel or promote locally if you ask.

3. Merch Store (Direct Revenue)

Print-on-demand: No inventory (Printful, Printify)
T-shirts, hoodies, hats: Standard merch
Physical music: Vinyl, CDs (if demand exists)
Digital downloads: Bandcamp integration

ðŸ’¡ Pro tip: POD is safest for new artists. Printful integrates with WordPress/WooCommerce or Squarespace.

4. Email List Building (Critical)

Lead magnet: "Free download" for email address
Newsletter signup: "Get tour dates first"
Platform independence: Own your fan list (Instagram/TikTok can ban)
Segmentation: Fans by location (target tour marketing)

ðŸ’¡ Pro tip: Email list is your insurance policy. If social platforms ban you, you still reach fans. Start day one.

5. Electronic Press Kit (EPK)

Downloadable EPK: One-page PDF for venues/media
Includes: Bio, photos, music links, press quotes, tech rider
Video EPK: Live performance footage
Contact info: Booking, management, press

ðŸ’¡ Pro tip: Venues expect EPKs. Have downloadable link prominent. Make it easy to book you.

CASE STUDIES

Indie Band +127% Merch Sales After WordPress Launch

Platform: WordPress + WooCommerce + Printful

Before: Bandcamp only

After: WordPress site + merch store

Key features: Music embeds, email capture, POD merch

Marketing: Email list to 8,400 fans

Investment: $3,200 setup + $40/month

Merch sales: +127% year 1

Monthly revenue: $4,800 (merch + music)

Email open rate: 42% (industry: 18%)

"We relied on Bandcamp - great for music, bad for branding. Built WordPress site - embedded Spotify players for streaming, email capture offering free demo download for signup (now 8,400 subscribers), Printful POD merch store with no inventory. Merch sales up 127%, total monthly revenue $4,800. Email list is gold - 42% open rate when we announce tours or releases. WordPress plugins handle everything - worth every penny."

Solo Artist +84% Show Bookings After Squarespace EPK

Platform: Squarespace

Focus: Touring musician

Before: Social media only

Key features: EPK download, tour calendar, music embeds

Booking focus: Venue research, direct outreach

Build time: 2 weeks

Show bookings: +84% year 1

Tour revenue: $67,000 (vs $36K previous)

Press coverage: 12 features (EPK worked)

"Venues need professional materials - fast. Built Squarespace site with downloadable EPK (bio, photos, music links, press quotes, tech rider), tour calendar with Ticketmaster links, embedded Spotify players. Started emailing venues with EPK link - show bookings up 84%, tour revenue doubled to $67,000. Got 12 press features because journalists found everything in one place. Squarespace's professional templates made me look legit. Should have done this years ago."

âœ… CHOOSE WORDPRESS (9/10) IF:

Best for: Serious musicians, bands, those building direct-to-fan businesses

âœ… CHOOSE SQUARESPACE (8/10) IF:

  • â€¢ You want beautiful, easy-to-maintain site
  • â€¢ You need built-in merch store
  • â€¢ You're not technical
  • â€¢ You value aesthetics
  • â€¢ You want to launch quickly

Best for: Most solo artists, bands wanting professional site without technical hassle

âœ… CHOOSE BANDZOOGLE (7/10) IF:

  • â€¢ You want all-in-one musician platform
  • â€¢ You want music-focused features out of the box
  • â€¢ You don't want to manage technical details
  • â€¢ You're starting out
  • â€¢ Budget is limited ($20-30/month)

Best for: New artists, hobbyists, those wanting hands-off music platform

ðŸ’¡ MY RECOMMENDATION

Choose WordPress (9/10) if you're building a music business. Merch store, email list, EPK downloads - everything to monetize your music directly. Squarespace (8/10) for easiest professional site with built-in merch. Bandzoogle (7/10) for hands-off all-in-one platform. Remember: Your website is your home base - own your fanbase, capture emails, sell merch directly. Streaming platforms pay pennies - your site is where you make real money.
